A. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The CommerceCentre@Buena Park, Building C abides by the emergency response procedures and policies detailed in the Emergency Ammonia Action Plan manual.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:

1.) To save lives.
2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
3.) To protect the environment.
4.) To minimize property damage.

The facility occupants (tenants), plan to evacuate during an ammonia emergency scenario.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate any facility changes.


B. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The ammonia refrigeration system is located on a 55-acre parcel currently owned by Overton Moore Properties (OMP) and formerly owned by Albertson's (who merged with Lucky)[2].  The business park, called the CommerceCentre @ Buena Park, is located east of the juncture of the I-5 freeway and 22 freeway, and bounded by Knott Avenue to the East, Caballero Boulevard to the West and South, and the Fullerton Creek, Orange County Flood Control Channel to the North.  The location of the facility with respect to the local area is shown in Figure 1.

The CommerceCentre @ Buena Park, Building C facility is occupied by a commercial/industrial tenant.  The facility consists of a warehouse storage building of approximately 140,000 square feet.  The building is cooled via an ammonia refrigeration system that maintains a maximum charge of 12,300 pounds of ammonia.  Figure 2 shows the layout of the CommerceCentre @ Buena Park, Building C facility.

Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the cooling system for the CommerceCentre @ Buena Park, Building C facility.  The ammonia is circulated throughout the

system using pressure differentials created by compressors and liquid pumps.  The majority of the refrigeration equipment is contained in the engine room with evaporators located throughout the warehouse.

The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the high pressure receiver to the high-temperature liquid pump recirculator (LPR-H1), the intercooler, and 12 high temperature evaporators (dock and Coolers 5 and 6). The LPR-H1 supplies pumped liquid to 18 evaporators located in Cooler Rooms 1, 2, 3, 4, and 7. The rooms serviced by these evaporators range from 35?F to 45?F.  The evaporators use fans to blow air across the coils, which transfer heat from the room to the ammonia inside the coils.  As this occurs, the ammonia partially vaporizes (boils) and is returned back to the LPR-H1. 

The LPR-H1 also supplies liquid to the low-temperature liquid pump recirculator (LPR-L1).  The LPR-L1 supplies pumped liquid to 6 evaporators located in Freezer 8 (-15?F ).  The resulting liquid/vapor mixture (suction) from these evaporators is returned to the LPR-L1. 

The compressors (two stage) maintain a constant pressure in the respective liquid pump recirculator vessel based on the suction setpoint.  There are two booster compressors that collect low pressure vapor (6.2 psig) from the LPR-L1.  Discharge from the booster compressors (50 - 65 psig) flows to the intercooler where it is dispersed below the liquid level.  The intercooler serves to cool the super-heated vapor from the booster compressors prior to the second stage of compression at the high stage compressors (3).  These compressors pull medium temperature vapor (50 - 65 psig) from the intercooler and LPR-H1. The hot gas (high stage compressor discharge - 150 psig) is delivered to the condensers (3), where the latent heat in the ammonia vapor is discharged to the atmosphere, causing it to condense.  Hot gas is also used for defrosting the evaporator coils on an automatic timed cy

cle.  The condensers drain the high pressure liquid back to the high pressure receiver. 

The maximum inventory of ammonia at the CommerceCentre @ Buena Park, Building C facility, is 12,300 pounds. 

C. HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY

Worst Case Release Result Summary

The worst case release scenario is a release of the total quantity of ammonia in the largest vessel in the ammonia refrigeration system, taking into account administrative controls that limit the maximum quantity in the vessel.  If a vessel is located inside a building, the EPA allows a passive mitigation factor of 55% to be used in calculating the release rate to the outside atmosphere when the release is enclosed by a building.

The Low Temperature Liquid Pump Recirculator results in the highest release rate, and will therefore be used for the worst case release scenario.  The vessel is located outside the building, so no passive mitigation was considered.  The maximum ammonia charge of 12,300 lbs is limited by the vessel size.  

Release of the maximum quantity of ammonia that can be stored in a vessel (Liquid Pump Recirculator) is 6,270 pounds in 10 minutes.  The EPA-approved guidance document, "Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration", reference tables were used to determine the maximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in urban conditions.

For analyzing the worst case release scenario, EPA requires the use of the most pessimistic meteorological conditions that will allow for the maximum downwind exposure.  Low wind speeds (1.5 m/s) and stable atmospheric conditions (F stability) will allow the gas cloud to travel as far as possible by limiting cloud dispersion.  The results are conservative.

EPA's "Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration", November 1998, Exhibit 4-4 was used to find the downwind distance for the worst case release to 200 ppm in an urban setting.  The RMP*Comp? Model developed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and EP

A was used to prepare the data in this guidance document.  This guidance document provides data for ammonia refrigeration systems and will ensure consistency throughout the industry.

This release reaches off site and may impact population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release.  

Alternative Release Result Summary

A release of ammonia resulting from a 1.25 inch diameter hole in a pipe.  The release rate of ammonia due to the pressure of the tank is 166 pounds per minute.  The meteorological conditions used were 3 meters per second wind speed, and D staiblity.  Reference tables in the Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration were used to determine the meaximum distance to the toxic endpoint of 200 ppm in urban conditions.  This release reaches off site and may impact population receptors.  No environmental receptors were affected by this potential release. 


D. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The CommerceCentre@Buena Park, Building C facility has many safety features, including those implemented on the ammonia refrigeration system.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with the State Office of Emergency Services' California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program as well as Cal-OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM), and Federal EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP), Program 3 requirements.

The ammonia refrigeration system at the CommerceCentre@Buena Park facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code, which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  These safety features include an ammonia diffusion tank, ammonia sensors in the machine room, cold storage areas, dock areas and relief header, pressure relief valves to protects vessels' int

egrity, and automatic shut down systems that prevent equipment damage and ammonia releases.  In the event of ammonia detection, audible and visual alarms are triggered throughout the facility. 

The operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system is contracted out to a professional refrigeration firm.  This ensures that the system is maintained properly by refrigeration experts and according to industry standards.  The refrigeration contractor is available 24 hours per day.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the systems are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks are noted and repaired immediately.

In addition to the Uniform Mechanical Code, the facility will operate in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines.  In particular, the IIAR Bulletin 110, "Startup, Inspection, and Maintenance of Ammonia Refrigeration Systems."

E. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

This refrigeration system is scheduled for startup in October 2001.  Since it is under new ownership, there is no accident history to report.  Prior to the current ownership (Overton Moore Properties), the facility was owned and operated by Lucky Stores, Inc.  The Risk Management Plan (June 20, 1999) data for the Lucky Stores, Inc. system also reported no ammonia release in the previous five years that resulted in on-site deaths, injuries, significant property damage, or reported incidences of off-site consequences.

F. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The CommerceCentre@Buena Park, Building C facility has an emergency action plan in effect.  The Emergency Action Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP document, which is maintained at

the facility.  Emergency response activities are coordinated with the Orange County Fire Authority and the local fire houses.  If necessary, the facility will call 9-1-1 to alert the local Police and Fire Departments.

Other responders will be called as needed, including the Orange County Hazardous Materials Response Team and the facility's refrigeration contractor.  If a release exceeds the federal reporting quantity of 100 pounds for ammonia, the National Response Center will be called.

As Building C is occupied by an industrial tenant, the tenant will be responsible for evacuating and ensuring the safety of its own employees in case of an emergency evacuation.  Evacuation drills are performed at least annually.  Other training received by Building C employees includes: ammonia awareness, what to do in case of emergency, and where to go when an evacuation is called.  Emergency coordination with Building C occupants will occur as needed.

The following summarizes the notification procedures at the facility:

1. First call 911 on an internal/land line phone for the Buena Park Fire Department and  police department.  The Orange County Fire Authority can also be reached at (714) 744-0463. 

2. If an ammonia release exceeds 1000 pounds or 135 gallons (Federal Reportable Quantity) in any 24 hour period, call the Governor's Office of Emergency Services (OES) Chemical Emergency Planning & Response Center 1-800-852-7550 [24 hour #].

3. If additional help is required for an ammonia spill or leak, the facility can call Chemtrec - Manufacturing Chemists Association 1-800-424-9300.

4. If an ammonia release exceeds 1000 pounds or 135 gallons, call the National Response Center 1-800-424-8802 [24 hours, 7 days].

5. If serious injuries or harmful exposures to workers occurs, call the nearest Cal-OSHA Office at 626-966-1166.

6. If an employee ingests ammonia, the Poison Control Center can be reached 24 hours per day at 1-800-342-9293.

7. Notify the local regulatory agency: O

range County Fire Authority at (714) 744-0463. 

8. Call for assistance with chemical cleanup.  The ammonia supply company, LaRoche Industries can be reached at 1-800-826-0263; A contracted pump out company, United Pumping Service, Inc. can be reached at 626-961-9326 (an open Purchase Order is maintained).  Do NOT use a regular vacuum truck, as they are not equipped to handle chemicals of this type.

9*. If any amount of ammonia is released into the storm drain, contact the Department of Fish and Game at (562) 590-5132 .

*The Department of Fish and Game receives a copy of the OES report; however if a significant amount is spilled into the storm drain, they would appreciate being contacted directly.


G. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Hazard Review, including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and a Facility "What If" Walkthrough, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at the CommerceCentre@Buena Park, Building C facility located at 6535 Caballero Blvd. in Buena Park, California.  Many of the recommendations are complete and implemented as of the system startup date in October 2001.  All of the remaining recommendations are scheduled to be complete by October 2002.

The Seismic Assessment, performed on October 22, 2001, by a licensed structural engineer, also generated mitigation measures to improve the seismic adequacy of the refrigeration system and the building itself.  The Seismic Recommendations are scheduled to be complete in October 2002.

R02: Ensure that tenant conducts awareness training for all on site employees providing: 1) dangers associated with ammonia; 2) recognition of an ammonia release; 3) action to take in case of a release; 4) where to evacuate, if necessary.

R03: Ensure that the on-site employer conducts evacuation drills and invites the local fire station to participate.

R04: Coordinate emergency response activities with local r

esponders i.e. police, Orange Co. Fire Authority, local fire station. 

R05: Establish equipment operating  parameters and discuss with operator.

R06:  Ensure no combustible materials are stored in the machinery room.

R07: Include relief valve replacement schedule of every 5 years (per IIAR guidelines) in Mechanical Integrity section of PSM/RMP.

R08: Implement Preventive Maintenance per IIAR Bulletin 110.

R09: Include ammonia detector/shut down test per manufacturer's recommendations or at least yearly and include in the Mechanical Integrity section of the PSM/RMP.

R10: Consider installing an eyewash/safety shower station outside of machine room. Determine where a liquid ammonia spill will migrate from the floor drain in machinery room. 

R11: Develop notification procedures (Orange County Sanitation if release goes offsite) for liquid  ammonia release down drain. 

R12:  Develop emergency response plan for decision lines of notification including the situation of liquid ammonia in machine room going down the floor drain.  

R13: Ensure vessel is referred to as recirculator on all drawings.  New drawings should says "RECIRCULATOR" instead of "RECEIVER".

R14: Include testing of recirculator alarms and switches in maintenance program.

R15: Include oil draining procedures in operating procedures to ensure operator safety.

R16: Consider installing an ammonia sensor inside the LPR-L1 shed area.

R17: Clean the liquid transfer unit and apply Polyguard CA-9 or CA-14 corrosion coating with Alumaguard 60 applied around the vessel shell per manufacturer's recommendations.

R18: Include maintenance inspection for corrosion on periodic walk down of ammonia system.  At a minimum, a formal visual inspection of the vessel for potential exterior corrosion and/or insulation degradation should be conducted annually. 

R19: Consider installation of traffic barriers to protect the vessel if they are not already present.

R20: Evaluate coil cleaning schedule.  Follow IIAR Bullet

in 110 recommendations for cleaning and inspecting evaporators.

R21: Consider installation of new roof access. 

R22:  Consider installing "steps" to walk over the ammonia pipelines.

R23: Ensure that the on-site personnel and/or the refrigeration maintenance contractor follows a lockout / tagout program.

R24:  Need to determine how often the refrigeration contractor will be on site.  Consider training on-site operators to conduct walkdowns of the engine room to log certain parameters. 

R25: Obtain a new set of piping diagrams that includes the water tank.
